titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Trumbull Ladd Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:41

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection includes correspondence pertaining to George Trumbull Ladd's professional life and international travels, particularly to East Asia and southern Europe; reprints of articles; oversize photographs of Ladd and his wife with dignitaries and others in Japan and Korea; a syllabus of Ladd's lectures on philosophy at Yale University; and some letters of Frances Ladd, George Trumbull Ladd's second wife.

langmaterial.language: The materials are in English, Italian, and Japanese.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Ladd, 1931. Gift of Elizabeth Wadhams Lawrence Trust, 2015.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George Trumbull Ladd Papers (MS 1371). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first accession consists of two letters by George Trumbull Ladd to unidentified recipients, and reprints of more than eighty articles and reviews, bound in four volumes.

The second accession contains late 19th and early 20th century correspondence pertaining to George Trumbull Ladd's international travels, particularly to East Asia and southern Europe; oversize photographs of Ladd and his wife with dignitaries and others in Japan and Korea; a syllabus of Ladd's lectures on philosophy at Yale University; and some letters of Frances Ladd, George Trumbull Ladd's second wife.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Trumbull Ladd, psychologist, philosopher, and theologian, was born on January 19, 1842 in Painesville, Ohio. In 1864 he graduated from Western Reserve College and in 1869 from Andover Theological Seminary. Ladd was a minister from 1869-1879 when he accepted the chair of philosophy at Bowdoin College. He moved to New Haven in 1881 and for forty years was associated with Yale University. In 1892 Ladd and others founded the American Psychological Association and served as its second president. He frequently traveled to Japan, lecturing on philosophy. Ladd died on August 8, 1921.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged by accession.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The volumes were given to the Yale Library by Mrs. Ladd in 1931, and were transferred to Manuscripts and Archives from Sterling Memorial Library stacks. Once at Manuscripts and Archives, the letters were originally in the Miscellaneous Manuscripts and Yale Miscellaneous Manuscripts collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession includes two letters by George Trumbull Ladd to incompletely identified recipients, and reprints of more than eighty articles and reviews, bound in four volumes. In a 1903 letter to "Professor Helder", Ladd describes his past and projected work in the field of philosophy of religion. In an undated letter to "Dr. Bacon"-probably either Benjamin Wisner Bacon or his father, Leonard Woolsey Bacon-he discusses the speed of nervous impulses, and speaks of the work of Edward Wheeler Scripture at the Yale psychological laboratory.

did.unittitle: Essays : 4 bound volumes of printed matter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession contains late 19th and early 20th century correspondence pertaining to George Trumbull Ladd's international travels, particularly to East Asia and southern Europe; oversize photographs of Ladd and his wife with dignitaries and others in Japan and Korea; a syllabus of Ladd's lectures on philosophy at Yale University; and some letters of Frances Ladd, George Trumbull Ladd's second wife.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The correspondence and papers in this accession were originally bundled in trifold groupings, some of which were labeled by Ladd or previous custodians with descriptions of their contents. Processors flattened material in these bundles. Correspondence is labeled according to original bundle labels, when provided, or by date, if labels were not provided.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The accession is arranged in three groupings: correspondence, photographs, and teaching materials.
